LACROSSE PRACTICE
WILL BEGIN TODAY
Carrol Urges Candidates to Be
Present at Workouts; Few
Regulars Are Lost

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., OCTOBER 25, 1927

SOPHOMORE CLASS
WILL MEET TODAY
Organization of sophomore
class athletics will be held today at 12.30 in the C. E. Hall.
An effort was made last Tuesday to organize the various
sports, but because of lack of
publicity the meeting was
poorly attended and the organization_ was pushed back to
Tuesday.
Edward Beuwkes, who was
in charge of the freshman track
team last year, has again accepted the appointment, as has
John Deets, who handled the
frosh football team in 1926.
The class of 1931 seems to
have a very good football outfit this year, and the results of
the Frosh-Soph contest will
be looked forward to with interest.

Preparation for the coming lacrosse season begins today. At
Thursday's Assembly Manager Carroll stated that fall practice was
a very essential part of a successful season, for at this time the beginners will be taught the fundamentals of the game. The men will
have a chance to get all the preliminary practice over with, so that
When the 'spring season opens they
can get down to business, without
any unnecessary fumbles or errors
due to lack of experience.
Practice will be held regularly on
Tuesday, Thursday and Friday at
four o'clock, from now until the Hopkins Graduate
Christmas recess and longer if the

VARSITY CLUB WILL
JAY
ADOPT STANDARD PIN
Club Expresses Regret at Illness of Thomas Magill,
Line Coach

GRIDDERS AVENGE LAST YEAR'S
LOSS AS LOYOLA BOWS 28-21

SIX DELEGATES AT
"Y" CONFERENCE
Six Hopkins representatives
attended the Y. M. C. A. TriState Conference held last
week-end at Newark, Delaware. They were Lowell Ensor, president of the "Y," E.
Foster Dowell, Hubert Klemme, Thomas Perkins, Emily
Austin, and E. A. Schaal.
The local delegation left the
campus early Friday afternoon by automobile, returning
to Baltimore on Sunday.

Several important questions were
taken up at a meeting of the Varsity
Club, held last Thursday in the
Civil Engineering Building with
David Kaufman, president of the
organization, in the chair. The
question of the adoption of a new
pin was put before the members.
After some discussion it was decided by an overwhelming majority
to adopt a new pin on which a blue
"H" will be prominently displayed.
The three pins now being worn, one
for each of the major sports, football, track and lacrosse, will be discarded. The new pin will be small Sir Rodney Rodd
and around the outer rim, encircling
To Lecture Thursday
the "H", the words "Varsity Club,
University"
The Johns Hopkins
will appear.
English Diplomat Will Deliver First
Sympathy for Magill

The Varsity Club, on behalf of
the University, expressed deep regret at the illness of Thomas Magill, line coach of football, member
of the Executive Board of the Club,
and graduate member of the Student Council. Magill has been very
ill for two months, and as a token
of affection that the members of the
University hold for him, the Club
voted to present him with a book.
In the afternoon, there was, in
addition, a meeting of the Executive Board of the Johns Hopkins
Alumni Varsity Club at a dinner
given at the Merchants Club. Henry Iddins, Graduate Manager of
Athletics, Strader and Kaufman attended. The Alumni also expressed a vote of sympathy for Mr. Magill, and decided to present him
with some token of their appreciation of his services to the University.

PRICE 5 CENTS

Public Address of Year

The Rt. Hon. Sir Rodney Rodd,
English nobleman and diplomatist,
will deliver the first public lecture of
the year Thursday afternoon at five
o'clock in the Civil Engineering
Building. The lecture w11 be on a
topic with which Sir Rodney Rodd
has had a life-long acquaintance:
"Diplomacy, The Old and The
New."
Holds Many Honors

Sir Rodney, besides being a mu.:
ber of the Privy Council, is a knight
of the grand cross of the Bath and
the holder of many other distinguished orders. He is a man who
has a practical knowledge of diplomacy, having devoted his entire life
to the diplomatic service of the British Empire: He entered the service
after leaving Oxford, and for a
few years was stationed at Berlin
as diplomatic attache. Subsequently, before the beginning of the century, his duty took him to Athens,
Rome, Cairo and Zanzibar. From
1901 to 1908 he served as special
minister first to Afghanistan then to
Sweden. In 1908 he was appointed
ambassador to Italy, a post which
he held during the war. His next
mission took him to Egypt, where
he remained three years. From
1921 to 1923 he served as British
delegate to the League of Nations.
Sir Rodney has written a number
of books dealing with various
phases of diplomacy. With such a
wide experience to draw from, his
lecture should be one of outstanding
interest.

Mallonee Carries V Ball Over
Twice, Lawrence and
Pindell Once
LOYOLA ALMOST TIES
Long Pass, Child to Tanton, Almost Gains Touchdown in
Last Quarter
As Jack Lawrence nailed the flying Tanton on. Hopkins' 10-yard
line in the last second of play at
Homewood Saturday, the loud
shout of apprehension rising from
the Hopkins stands changed to a
long sigh of relief. It was a magnificent bid for the game which a
fighting Loyola team made in the
last quarter. A pass from Child to
Tanton, which was illegally interfered with by Bobby Lyons, gave
Loyola the ball on Hopkins' 19-yard
line. After several line bucks, Cannon fumbled and Schmedike recovered for Hopkins. On the third
down, Lyons kicked to Loyola's 20yard line and it looked as though
the game was over.
Last Threat Fails

Then came the climax of a spectacular contest. With time left for
only one play, Child received the
pass from center add warded off
several Jay tacklers, while Tan-ton
sped down the field past Lawrence
and finally past Lyons. Child threw
the pass, close to 50 yards, and Tanton made the catch with no one between him and the goal line. Lawrence, however, was close on his
heels and finally brought him to
earth on the 10-yard line. The gun
went off a moment later and Hopkins had won an epic contest,
28-21.

ATTRACTIVE?
One of the most inaccurate of all the inaccuracies that have
appeared in the NEWS-LETTER in quite a while was the headline
of an article in last Friday's issue. The headline read "Attractive
List of Assemblies Planned," but with the exception of a circular
talk by Mr. J. Stitt Wilson, we could see nothing attractive on the
entire program.
As a matter of fact, apparently only four assemblies have been
prepared. Two are automatic dates that come every year—the
freshman-sophomore debate and the Adams contest; one is Mr.
Wilson's speech, and the fourth is "pending." The latter, if it
materializes, will be an address by a Congressman.
- This unimposing array could hardly be termed "attractive."
Mr. Wilson, although a most desirable speaker, does not represent
any great effort on the part of those in charge of the assemblies,
for he has been lecturing at many of the Eastern colleges all fall.
Congressman Reed has not been definitely booked, though his
talk will probably be stimulating if he is secured.
There are many people of real prominence in the country who
would probably be glad to address the student body of Johns
Hopkins University. Dr. Will Durant has lectured at Lafayette,
M. Andre Maurois at Princeton, and Bertrand Russell at several
American colleges. There is no reason why men of similar
caliber cannot be secured for Hopkins.
The huge crowd that packed the C. E. Hall to hear Mr. Arthur
Garfield Hays last spring is evidence of the fact that upper classmen and faculty members will attend the weekly assemblies if
interesting speakers are obtained. The Adams debate contest is
thrilling indeed, we admit, but think how much more of a thrill
the student body would receive from Will Durant or Bertrand
Russell. How about it, committee?

ONE CAN'T KNOW EVERYTHING, THOUGH!
Some day, if you find life dull and dreary, and you are sorely
in need of stimulation, try listening in on a lecture in the College
for Teachers. Pick one more or less at random, but try to get
one during which the instructor asks questions of the members
of his class. And then, if fortune smiles upon you, you will be
blessed with hearing one like this: "Does anyone in the class
know what was the first book published in America?" Answer
from a young thing in the front row: "Wasn't it the Bible, professor ?"
Yea, even in "college"!

NOTE ON THE GAME
The football team is to be congratulated on the amount of "pep"
shown last Saturday when it played Loyola. And we don't refer
to pep shown by the team—we mean pep shown by the cheering
sections. It is generally gratifying to note that the undergraduate
school hasn't reached a complete state of atrophy. Keep it up,
boys!

JOHN EARLE UHLER

At a time when the Little Theater was growing to be a phenomenon in our stage history, it was natural that devotees of the
drama at Hopkins should organize themselves for an attempt to
establish a Little Theater here. Early in 1921, several members
of the faculty, a few alumni and a handful of students elected officers, adopted a constitution and started at work as a simple production of one-act plays.
These early productions, staged in the top floor of the Barn
for a small but very sympathetic and interested audience, consisted mostly of original plays—that is, plays written by members
of the organization; and these plays, as I recall, were for the most
part adaptations of short stories.
The original interest grew apace until the management in a few
months felt justified in presenting a bill before the public. The
Vagabond Theater, then in the Saint James Apartments, was
rented for the premiere, and a bill of three one-act plays, one of
which was original, was offered with entirely satisfactory results.
The chief significance of this effort lay in the one original play,
called Hamlet. There was about as much similarity between it and
Hamlet as between a weed and an aged oak, but it was original,
and it showed some promise of better work on the part of the
playwright.
It was and is in this respect that the Playshop should find its
greatest success, namely, in encouraging the local playwright.
There is a place for the classics in the activities of the organization, but without some promotion of the writing of plays on the
part of the members, the Little Theater is in danger of degenerating into a poor imitation of the professional theater.
In the summer of 1921 the first production was staged for the
students of the Summer School, a precedent which has been followed each year to the present time, and which, I hope, will be
continued. Such plays as Garrick's Lying Valet, Rostrand's The
Romancers and Mitchell's New York Idea have been put on before
the Summer School students.
These various activities were successful enough to encourage
the members of the Playshop to agitate the question of securing
a theater of their own. After consultation with President Goodnow, Dr. French and Dr. Goodnow and others examining the
attics of the various buildings, it was finally decided that the best
available place was the old so-called gymnasium, which was then
filled to the rafters with rocks belonging to the Geology Department and with cannon and other equipment belonging to the
Military Department. Rocks and cannon were soon removed and
the careful plans made by the Playshop committee soon transformed the building into a very attractive Little Theater.
Here, however, lies a tale. To work the necessary changes in
the old building, a fund of about $2000 was required. In order
to secure this sum, the Playshop management appealed through
President Goodnow to the Board of Trustees for a loan, with the
provision that the loan would be repaid. The final balance was
returned to the Trustees just a month ago, so that now members
of the Playshop can indulge in a feeling of triumph, not only because they have performed creditably from an artistic point of view,
but because they have done what many artists fail to do; they
have succeeded financially. Incidentally, I may add that practically half the debt was paid solely during the past year, which
has been in many ways the most successful season of all.
The first performance in the new building consisted of three
one-act original plays, one a poetic drama, one a comedy and the
last a tragedy. In order to get the stage ready, the art staff and
some of the actors worked throughout the previous night until
five o'clock in the morning. This spirit was prevalent throughout the,organization and made possible such a successful performance that President Goodnow, who was in the audience, mentioned
in a speech before the alumni that the Hopkins Playshop, together
with the orchestra and the Tudor and Stuart Club, offered many
possibilities for the cultural development of the students at this
University.
A change in policy took place in the season of 1925. Up to that
time we had emphasized the so-called original play. In the season
of 1925-1926, however, although we did not neglect the original
play entirely, we planned a program unique in the history of the
theater in that each play of the program was connected in some
way with the play preceding. The season of 1925-1926 was a
season of period dramafl One play was chosen from each of
four periods—Farquhar's Beaus Stratagem from the Restoration
period; Hugo's Ruy Bias from the French Rennaisance ; Payne's
Captain Copp from the early American, and Fitch's Truth from
the modern period. In the season of 1926-1927 the season was
one of national drama. Five plays were presented—The Hraun
Farm from Icelandic literature; The Main Thing from the Russian; The Round Trip from the English; The Great Galerto from
the Spanish, and A Tear in the Devil's Eye from the Japanese.
I may add, too, that The Round Trip is the play from the pen of
John van Druten, author of Young Woodley, in which Glenn
Hunter starred. Mr. van Druten came to Baltimore for one production of the Round Trip, directed the play and took the leading
part.

THE HOMEWOOD PLAYSHOP
(Continued from page 2, column 2.)

During these two seasons, before the first performance of each
Play, a lecture was delivered on the subject of the drama of the
country concerned. Among the lecturers of last season were Jean
Jacques Copeau, the French dramatist and producer; Nicolai
Eveinoff, the Russian dramatist, and John van Druten. Also, during the season, some of the prominent actors and actresses playing
in the city were invited to the Playshop and entertained at tea.
Among them were Glenn Hunter, Helen Gadajar, Eva Le Gallienne, Crystal Herne, Rollo Peters and Peggy Ward.
Plans for the current season have not as yet fully developed,
although it is probable that Milne's Dover Road will be the first
offering. The program will probably be more definitely arranged
at the next meeting of the Board of Governors. This consists at
present of Dr. John C. French (chairman), Dr. Carol Wight,
Dr. H. C. Lancaster, Dr. Kemp Malone, Dr. Wilfred Beardsley,
Miss Alta E. Thompson and Mrs. Broadus Mitchell.
It should be kept in mind, finally, that the Homewood Playshop
IS not a college activity, but rather a laboratory for the stage of
the drama. The purpose is to cultivate, among the members, a
erary rather than a histrionic interest in the stage. Perhaps
'day a great Hopkins playwright will arise as a result.

A book entitled "What Happens"
has been written in Paris by a former George Washington College
part-time student and has been suppressed by United States customs
Officials. The book deals with the
life of a part-time college student
and the act of suppression leads us
to think more horrid things about
college morals. If the life of a
part-time student is deemed unfit
for perusal, what then must be the
story of the activities of a genuine,
full-fledged collegian?

John Stoll, a French exchange
student at Haverford College, contrasts American colleges and students with French universities. One
of his startling statements is that
the average American collegian
takes his work more seriously than
does his French cousin. However,
the American student does not take
as much interest in national and
world affairs as does the Frenchman, Stoll says. One of the features of the Sorbonne at Paris is
that students do
not go to classes
Which do not interest them.

Dr. Norman Fenton, psychologist
at the University of Ohio, conducted an experiment
in honesty among
female students recently with rather startling results. When
no restrictions were placed on the girls,
sixty-three per cent cheated; when
the instructor was in the room thirtY-one per cent cheated; when he
Was in an adjoining room the dehtiquents totaled thirty-nine per cent
of the class; and when he left the
building and placed the class on
its honor,
forty-five per cent used
illegal methods to find answers to
the
examination questions. Dr.
Penton also discovered that the best
students did not cheat, as none of
the A students were guilty and the
number of dishonest co-eds increased in proportion as their
grades decreased.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., OCTOBER 25, 1927

SOPHOMORE CLASS
WILL MEET TODAY
Organization of sophomore
class athletics will be held today at 12.30 in the C. E. Hall.
An effort was made last Tuesday to organize the various
sports, but because of lack of
publicity the meeting was
poorly attended and the organization_ was pushed back to
Tuesday.
Edward Beuwkes, who was
in charge of the freshman track
team last year, has again accepted the appointment, as has
John Deets, who handled the
frosh football team in 1926.
The class of 1931 seems to
have a very good football outfit this year, and the results of
the Frosh-Soph contest will
be looked forward to with interest.

Preparation for the coming lacrosse season begins today. At
Thursday's Assembly Manager Carroll stated that fall practice was
a very essential part of a successful season, for at this time the beginners will be taught the fundamentals of the game. The men will
have a chance to get all the preliminary practice over with, so that
When the 'spring season opens they
can get down to business, without
any unnecessary fumbles or errors
due to lack of experience.
Practice will be held regularly on
Tuesday, Thursday and Friday at
four o'clock, from now until the Hopkins Graduate

SIX DELEGATES AT
"Y" CONFERENCE
Six Hopkins representatives
attended the Y. M. C. A. TriState Conference held last
week-end at Newark, Delaware. They were Lowell Ensor, president of the "Y," E.
Foster Dowell, Hubert Klemme, Thomas Perkins, Emily
Austin, and E. A. Schaal.
The local delegation left the
campus early Friday afternoon by automobile, returning
to Baltimore on Sunday.

Several important questions were
taken up at a meeting of the Varsity
Club, held last Thursday in the
Civil Engineering Building with
David Kaufman, president of the
organization, in the chair. The
question of the adoption of a new
pin was put before the members.
After some discussion it was decided by an overwhelming majority
to adopt a new pin on which a blue
"H" will be prominently displayed.
The three pins now being worn, one
for each of the major sports, football, track and lacrosse, will be discarded. The new pin will be small Sir Rodney Rodd
and around the outer rim, encircling
To Lecture Thursday
the "H", the words "Varsity Club,
University"
The Johns Hopkins
will appear.
English Diplomat Will Deliver First
Sympathy for Magill

The Varsity Club, on behalf of
the University, expressed deep regret at the illness of Thomas Magill, line coach of football, member
of the Executive Board of the Club,
and graduate member of the Student Council. Magill has been very
ill for two months, and as a token
of affection that the members of the
University hold for him, the Club
voted to present him with a book.
In the afternoon, there was, in
addition, a meeting of the Executive Board of the Johns Hopkins
Alumni Varsity Club at a dinner
given at the Merchants Club. Henry Iddins, Graduate Manager of
Athletics, Strader and Kaufman attended. The Alumni also expressed a vote of sympathy for Mr. Magill, and decided to present him
with some token of their appreciation of his services to the University.

PRICE 5 CENTS

Public Address of Year

The Rt. Hon. Sir Rodney Rodd,
English nobleman and diplomatist,
will deliver the first public lecture of
the year Thursday afternoon at five
o'clock in the Civil Engineering
Building. The lecture w11 be on a
topic with which Sir Rodney Rodd
has had a life-long acquaintance:
"Diplomacy, The Old and The
New."
Holds Many Honors

Sir Rodney, besides being a mu.:
ber of the Privy Council, is a knight
of the grand cross of the Bath and
the holder of many other distinguished orders. He is a man who
has a practical knowledge of diplomacy, having devoted his entire life
to the diplomatic service of the British Empire: He entered the service
after leaving Oxford, and for a
few years was stationed at Berlin
as diplomatic attache. Subsequently, before the beginning of the century, his duty took him to Athens,
Rome, Cairo and Zanzibar. From
1901 to 1908 he served as special
minister first to Afghanistan then to
Sweden. In 1908 he was appointed
ambassador to Italy, a post which
he held during the war. His next
mission took him to Egypt, where
he remained three years. From
1921 to 1923 he served as British
delegate to the League of Nations.
Sir Rodney has written a number
of books dealing with various
phases of diplomacy. With such a
wide experience to draw from, his
lecture should be one of outstanding
interest.

LOYOLA ALMOST TIES
Long Pass, Child to Tanton, Almost Gains Touchdown in
Last Quarter
As Jack Lawrence nailed the flying Tanton on. Hopkins' 10-yard
line in the last second of play at
Homewood Saturday, the loud
shout of apprehension rising from
the Hopkins stands changed to a
long sigh of relief. It was a magnificent bid for the game which a
fighting Loyola team made in the
last quarter. A pass from Child to
Tanton, which was illegally interfered with by Bobby Lyons, gave
Loyola the ball on Hopkins' 19-yard
line. After several line bucks, Cannon fumbled and Schmedike recovered for Hopkins. On the third
down, Lyons kicked to Loyola's 20yard line and it looked as though
the game was over.
Last Threat Fails

Then came the climax of a spectacular contest. With time left for
only one play, Child received the
pass from center add warded off
several Jay tacklers, while Tan-ton
sped down the field past Lawrence
and finally past Lyons. Child threw
the pass, close to 50 yards, and Tanton made the catch with no one between him and the goal line. Lawrence, however, was close on his
heels and finally brought him to
earth on the 10-yard line. The gun
went off a moment later and Hopkins had won an epic contest,
28-21.

ATTRACTIVE?
One of the most inaccurate of all the inaccuracies that have
appeared in the NEWS-LETTER in quite a while was the headline
of an article in last Friday's issue. The headline read "Attractive
List of Assemblies Planned," but with the exception of a circular
talk by Mr. J. Stitt Wilson, we could see nothing attractive on the
entire program.
As a matter of fact, apparently only four assemblies have been
prepared. Two are automatic dates that come every year—the
freshman-sophomore debate and the Adams contest; one is Mr.
Wilson's speech, and the fourth is "pending." The latter, if it
materializes, will be an address by a Congressman.
- This unimposing array could hardly be termed "attractive."
Mr. Wilson, although a most desirable speaker, does not represent
any great effort on the part of those in charge of the assemblies,
for he has been lecturing at many of the Eastern colleges all fall.
Congressman Reed has not been definitely booked, though his
talk will probably be stimulating if he is secured.
There are many people of real prominence in the country who
would probably be glad to address the student body of Johns
Hopkins University. Dr. Will Durant has lectured at Lafayette,
M. Andre Maurois at Princeton, and Bertrand Russell at several
American colleges. There is no reason why men of similar
caliber cannot be secured for Hopkins.
The huge crowd that packed the C. E. Hall to hear Mr. Arthur
Garfield Hays last spring is evidence of the fact that upper classmen and faculty members will attend the weekly assemblies if
interesting speakers are obtained. The Adams debate contest is
thrilling indeed, we admit, but think how much more of a thrill
the student body would receive from Will Durant or Bertrand
Russell. How about it, committee?

ONE CAN'T KNOW EVERYTHING, THOUGH!
Some day, if you find life dull and dreary, and you are sorely
in need of stimulation, try listening in on a lecture in the College
for Teachers. Pick one more or less at random, but try to get
one during which the instructor asks questions of the members
of his class. And then, if fortune smiles upon you, you will be
blessed with hearing one like this: "Does anyone in the class
know what was the first book published in America?" Answer
from a young thing in the front row: "Wasn't it the Bible, professor ?"
Yea, even in "college"!

NOTE ON THE GAME
The football team is to be congratulated on the amount of "pep"
shown last Saturday when it played Loyola. And we don't refer
to pep shown by the team—we mean pep shown by the cheering
sections. It is generally gratifying to note that the undergraduate
school hasn't reached a complete state of atrophy. Keep it up,
boys!

JOHN EARLE UHLER

At a time when the Little Theater was growing to be a phenomenon in our stage history, it was natural that devotees of the
drama at Hopkins should organize themselves for an attempt to
establish a Little Theater here. Early in 1921, several members
of the faculty, a few alumni and a handful of students elected officers, adopted a constitution and started at work as a simple production of one-act plays.
These early productions, staged in the top floor of the Barn
for a small but very sympathetic and interested audience, consisted mostly of original plays—that is, plays written by members
of the organization; and these plays, as I recall, were for the most
part adaptations of short stories.
The original interest grew apace until the management in a few
months felt justified in presenting a bill before the public. The
Vagabond Theater, then in the Saint James Apartments, was
rented for the premiere, and a bill of three one-act plays, one of
which was original, was offered with entirely satisfactory results.
The chief significance of this effort lay in the one original play,
called Hamlet. There was about as much similarity between it and
Hamlet as between a weed and an aged oak, but it was original,
and it showed some promise of better work on the part of the
playwright.
It was and is in this respect that the Playshop should find its
greatest success, namely, in encouraging the local playwright.
There is a place for the classics in the activities of the organization, but without some promotion of the writing of plays on the
part of the members, the Little Theater is in danger of degenerating into a poor imitation of the professional theater.
In the summer of 1921 the first production was staged for the
students of the Summer School, a precedent which has been followed each year to the present time, and which, I hope, will be
continued. Such plays as Garrick's Lying Valet, Rostrand's The
Romancers and Mitchell's New York Idea have been put on before
the Summer School students.
These various activities were successful enough to encourage
the members of the Playshop to agitate the question of securing
a theater of their own. After consultation with President Goodnow, Dr. French and Dr. Goodnow and others examining the
attics of the various buildings, it was finally decided that the best
available place was the old so-called gymnasium, which was then
filled to the rafters with rocks belonging to the Geology Department and with cannon and other equipment belonging to the
Military Department. Rocks and cannon were soon removed and
the careful plans made by the Playshop committee soon transformed the building into a very attractive Little Theater.
Here, however, lies a tale. To work the necessary changes in
the old building, a fund of about $2000 was required. In order
to secure this sum, the Playshop management appealed through
President Goodnow to the Board of Trustees for a loan, with the
provision that the loan would be repaid. The final balance was
returned to the Trustees just a month ago, so that now members
of the Playshop can indulge in a feeling of triumph, not only because they have performed creditably from an artistic point of view,
but because they have done what many artists fail to do; they
have succeeded financially. Incidentally, I may add that practically half the debt was paid solely during the past year, which
has been in many ways the most successful season of all.
The first performance in the new building consisted of three
one-act original plays, one a poetic drama, one a comedy and the
last a tragedy. In order to get the stage ready, the art staff and
some of the actors worked throughout the previous night until
five o'clock in the morning. This spirit was prevalent throughout the,organization and made possible such a successful performance that President Goodnow, who was in the audience, mentioned
in a speech before the alumni that the Hopkins Playshop, together
with the orchestra and the Tudor and Stuart Club, offered many
possibilities for the cultural development of the students at this
University.
A change in policy took place in the season of 1925. Up to that
time we had emphasized the so-called original play. In the season
of 1925-1926, however, although we did not neglect the original
play entirely, we planned a program unique in the history of the
theater in that each play of the program was connected in some
way with the play preceding. The season of 1925-1926 was a
season of period dramafl One play was chosen from each of
four periods—Farquhar's Beaus Stratagem from the Restoration
period; Hugo's Ruy Bias from the French Rennaisance ; Payne's
Captain Copp from the early American, and Fitch's Truth from
the modern period. In the season of 1926-1927 the season was
one of national drama. Five plays were presented—The Hraun
Farm from Icelandic literature; The Main Thing from the Russian; The Round Trip from the English; The Great Galerto from
the Spanish, and A Tear in the Devil's Eye from the Japanese.
I may add, too, that The Round Trip is the play from the pen of
John van Druten, author of Young Woodley, in which Glenn
Hunter starred. Mr. van Druten came to Baltimore for one production of the Round Trip, directed the play and took the leading
part.

THE HOMEWOOD PLAYSHOP
(Continued from page 2, column 2.)

During these two seasons, before the first performance of each
Play, a lecture was delivered on the subject of the drama of the
country concerned. Among the lecturers of last season were Jean
Jacques Copeau, the French dramatist and producer; Nicolai
Eveinoff, the Russian dramatist, and John van Druten. Also, during the season, some of the prominent actors and actresses playing
in the city were invited to the Playshop and entertained at tea.
Among them were Glenn Hunter, Helen Gadajar, Eva Le Gallienne, Crystal Herne, Rollo Peters and Peggy Ward.
Plans for the current season have not as yet fully developed,
although it is probable that Milne's Dover Road will be the first
offering. The program will probably be more definitely arranged
at the next meeting of the Board of Governors. This consists at
present of Dr. John C. French (chairman), Dr. Carol Wight,
Dr. H. C. Lancaster, Dr. Kemp Malone, Dr. Wilfred Beardsley,
Miss Alta E. Thompson and Mrs. Broadus Mitchell.
It should be kept in mind, finally, that the Homewood Playshop
IS not a college activity, but rather a laboratory for the stage of
the drama. The purpose is to cultivate, among the members, a
erary rather than a histrionic interest in the stage. Perhaps
'day a great Hopkins playwright will arise as a result.

to think more horrid things about

part-time student is deemed unfit
for perusal, what then must be the
story of the activities of a genuine,
full-fledged collegian?

John Stoll, a French exchange
student at Haverford College, contrasts American colleges and students with French universities. One
of his startling statements is that
the average American collegian
takes his work more seriously than
does his French cousin. However,
the American student does not take
as much interest in national and
world affairs as does the Frenchman, Stoll says. One of the features of the Sorbonne at Paris is
that students do
not go to classes

Dr. Norman Fenton, psychologist
at the University of Ohio, conducted an experiment
in honesty among
female students recently with rather startling results. When
no restrictions were placed on the girls,
sixty-three per cent cheated; when
the instructor was in the room thirtY-one per cent cheated; when he
Was in an adjoining room the dehtiquents totaled thirty-nine per cent
of the class; and when he left the
building and placed the class on
its honor,
forty-five per cent used
illegal methods to find answers to
the
examination questions. Dr.
Penton also discovered that the best
students did not cheat, as none of
the A students were guilty and the
number of dishonest co-eds increased in proportion as their
grades decreased.

Describes Institute

Dr. James Hart, associate Professor of Political Science, represented Johns Hopkins. When questioned concerning the matter, Dr.
Hart's first words were, "I think
it was distinctly a success." He
then proceeded to describe the daily
schedule. The round tables or discussion groups met in the morning
and one of the speakers made an
address to the general public. The
afternoons were free of any scheduled events. In the evenings another address would be given.
One of the most interesting features was an enormous searchlight
on the Monticello Hotel. It is said
that its beams can be seen for two
hundred miles.
